title: Renzo Burini
text:
Renzo Burini (; 10 October 1927 – 25 October 2019) was an <a href="Italians">Italian</a> professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and coach, who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Striker">striker</a> or as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29%23Winger">winger</a>. He was born in <a href="Palmanova">Palmanova</a>.
Club career.
Burini played for 12 seasons (330 games, 123 goals) in the Italian <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> for <a href="A.C.%20Milan">A.C. Milan</a> and <a href="S.S.%20Lazio">S.S. Lazio</a>. He made his debut with Milan at the age of 20, in an 8–1 win over <a href="A.S.%20Bari">Bari</a>, marking the occasion with a brace. He scored 12 goals during the <a href="1950%E2%80%9351%20Serie%20A">1950–51 Serie A</a> season, helping Milan capture the league title after a 44-year wait, and also won the <a href="Latin%20Cup">Latin Cup</a> later that season.
He is remembered by Lazio fans for his contribution to winning the first major trophy for the club, the <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> in 1958, and for his performance in two <a href="Derby%20della%20Capitale">Derby della Capitale</a> games against cross-city rivals <a href="A.S.%20Roma">Roma</a>: in Lazio's 1955 3–1 Rome Derby victory, he scored two goals, and in the 1958 edition of the Rome Derby, he scored one and set up <a href="Arne%20Selmosson">Arne Selmosson</a> for another in a 2–1 victory.
International career.
Burini made his debut for the <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy national football team</a> on 8 April 1951 in a game against <a href="Portugal%20national%20football%20team">Portugal</a> and scored on his debut. He was a member of the team which took part at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a>.
Style of play.
A versatile <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>, Burini could play both as a striker and as a winger, and was known for his outstanding pace and eye for goal.
